article:
The 'sphere of influence' is a region around a supermassive black hole in which
the gravitational potential of the black hole dominates the gravitational
potential of the host galaxy. The radius of the sphere of influence is called
the "influence radius".

There are two definitions in common use for the radius of the sphere of
influence. The first Peebles, J. (1972),
[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1972ApJ...178..371P Star Distribution Near a
Collapsed Object] is given by

r_h = \frac{GM_{\rm BH}}{\sigma^2}

where M BH is the mass of the black hole, \sigma is the
stellar velocity dispersion of the host bulge, and G is the
gravitational constant. The second definition {{Cite conference
  | first = D. last = Merritt authorlink = David Merritt title = Single and
  | Binary Black Holes and their Influence on Nuclear Structure booktitle =
  | Coevolution of Black Holes and Galaxies series = Carnegie Observatories
  | astrophysics series place = pages = 263-275 year = 2004 url = http://www.ca-
  | mbridge.org/us/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=0521824494#contributors}}
  | is the radius at which the enclosed mass in stars equals twice
  | M BH , i.e.

M_\star(r .

Which definition is most appropriate depends on the physical question that is
being addressed. The first definition takes into account the bulge's overall
effect on the motion of a star, since \sigma is determined in part
by stars that have moved far from the black hole. The second definition compares
the force from the black hole to the local force from the stars.

It is a minimum requirement that the sphere of influence be well resolved in
order that the mass of the black hole be determined dynamically. Marconi, A.
and Hunt, D. (2003), [http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2003ApJ...589L..21M The
Relation between Black Hole Mass, Bulge Mass, and Near-Infrared
Luminosity]
